close_symbols: struct sockaddr (definition, including sa_family member and its type/qualifiers)
sa_family_t typedef (underlying integer type and any qualifiers, e.g., volatile)
OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 (preprocessor macro that enables the AF_INET6 case)
explanation:
To decide if the switch controlling expression 'sa->sa_family' is an invariant, the analyzer must know what 'sa' can refer to at runtime and what the family field can contain. Specifically:

- OS_SockAddr_t (definition, including AddrData member): The function casts &Addr->AddrData to struct sockaddr. The layout/type of AddrData (e.g., whether it is a byte array, an embedded struct sockaddr, or contains constant/immutable data) determines whether sa->sa_family is runtime-varying or effectively constant.

- struct sockaddr (definition, including sa_family member and its type/qualifiers): The controlling expression is sa->sa_family; its declaration (field name, type, and any qualifiers like const/volatile) is needed to determine mutability and whether the expression could be invariant.

- sa_family_t typedef (underlying integer type and any qualifiers, e.g., volatile): Knowing the exact typedef and any qualifiers on the family field affects whether the value can change at runtime and whether the expression can be considered invariant under MISRA.

- AF_INET (macro/constant): The switch compares sa_family against AF_INET. The numeric value and its compile-time-constant nature are relevant when reasoning about possible values of the controlling expression.

- AF_INET6 (macro/constant): Same reason as AF_INET; also needed to reason about whether the switch can take alternate branches.

- OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 (preprocessor macro that enables the AF_INET6 case): This conditional controls whether the AF_INET6 case exists in the compiled code. If the macro is not defined, the switch has fewer cases and that affects whether the expression could be considered invariant in the compiled binary.

- struct sockaddr_in (definition) and struct sockaddr_in6 (definition): These determine the size computations (sizeof) used to set addrlen and also confirm that the cast from AddrData to struct sockaddr is consistent with expected socket address structures; they help confirm that sa->sa_family is intended to be populated from external (caller-provided) socket address data rather than a compile-time constant.

Together, these symbols let an analyzer determine whether sa->sa_family can vary at runtime (and thus the switch is non-invariant) or whether, due to types/qualifiers/layout/compile-time configuration, the controlling expression is effectively invariant (which would violate MISRA unless an exception applies).
